 Process Safety Information:
The El Mirage Wastewater Treatment Plant has only one regulated substance, Chlorine in a liquefied state. The one-ton cylinders are connected to the system via a Capitol Controls Switchover Vacuum Module 500 PPD (10 kg/h). A mechanical gas feeder valve is connected directly to the cylinder. This is a fault mechanism that will shut down the chlorine directly if failure occurs. The chlorine is then fed through a Capitol Controls Chlorine control unit Series 1450 this is fault mechanism. Lastly an Advanced gas detector by Capitol Controls monitors the system.

Toxicity: 

Summary of Toxic Effects:  
Inhalation is expected to be the primary route of occupational exposure to chlorine.   Chlorine liquid is corrosive to the eyes, mucous membranes and skin.  At normal atmospheric pressure and temperature, liquid chlorine readily vaporizes to gas.  Chlorine gas causes severe irritation of the eyes and respiratory tract with eye injury, restlessness, shortness of breath, cough, choking sensation, sneezing, running nose, chest pain, dizziness, headache, nausea, cyanosis (lack of oxygen in the blood) and respiratory failure.  Following respiratory tract injury, onset of severe breathing difficulties, including bronchitis, lung edema (accumulation of fluid in the lungs) and pneumonia, may be delayed and life threatening.  Exposure to concentrations as low as 5-10 ppm is reported to cause severe irritation of the eyes, nose and respiratory tract, which is intolerable after a few minutes.  The threshold odor concentration of chlorine is reported to range from 0.3-3.5 ppm. Repeated exposure to chlorine can result in loss of the ability to detect the odor of chlorine. 

Reactivity and Corrosiveness:

Conditions to Avoid:  
The presence of moisture in gaseous and liquid chlorine corrosive attack on most common metals. Chlorine will react with water or steam to produce toxic and corrosive fumes of hydrogen chloride.  



Materials to Avoid:  
Chlorine is a powerful oxidizing agent which reacts violently with a variety of substances over a broad range of conditions including reducing agents and combustible materials.

It should be kept away from materials such as acetylene, turpentine, other hydrocarbons, ammonia, hydrocarbons, certain metal hydrides, nitrides, oxides, sulfides, phosphides, easily oxidized materials, hydrogen ether, powdered metals, sulfur and aluminum.  Chlorine reacts with hydrogen sulfide and water forming hydrochloric acid.  It combines with carbon monoxide and sulfur dioxide to form phosgene and sulfuryl chloride, respectively, which are toxic and corrosive substances.  

Hazardous Decomposition Products:  
Chlorine does not decompose but reacts violently to form Hydrochloric Acid and other potentially toxic and/or corrosive substances.  Chlorine is stable in steel containers at room temperature when dry.  Intense local heat on steel walls can cause the steel to react and glow in presence of chlorine.

Permissible Exposure Limits:   
OSHA's PEL for Chlorine is 5ppm, STEL is 1ppm, NIOSH's IDLH is 10ppm

 Program 3 Prevention Program:

1.0 	Chlorination Process Specification

· Maximum Intended Inventory:  One-ton cylinders of chlorine are used at El Mirage WWTP.  The maximum intended inventory at the chlorine facility is 4 cylinders. 

· Safe Upper/Lower Limits: As referenced in the Chlorine Institute Manual, the following are considered safe limits for chlorine containers:

- Safe Upper Temperature - 150° F (Based on the limit for the fusible metal plug)
- Safe Lower Temperature - N/A
- Safe Upper Flow Rate - 400 lb/hr (Based on liquid chlorine at 35 psi, higher liquid discharge rates result in freezing)
- Safe Lower Flow Rate - N/A
- Concentration - 100%
- Safe Upper Flow Rate - 1 - 1.5 lb/hr (Based on gaseous chlorine in cylinders)

· Evaluation of Consequences of Deviations:  The consequence of deviation from design operating conditions listed above is:

	-	Exceeding the safe upper temperature  would cause the fusible plug to yield or melt, which would cause the c

hlorine to be released.

Attachment B provides schematics and design detail for the chlorination process.

2.0	Operating Procedures

All personnel who work with the chlorine and/or the clorination processes, and equipment covered by this plan have been given clear instructions and written procedures to help them.  Location of written procedures is also provided for ease of reference.  Copies of the various referenced Vendor O&M Guidance are provided in Attachment C.

· Steps for Each Operating Phase

- Initial Startup:
Procedures are provided in the process equipment Vendor's Operator and Maintenance (O&M) Guidance.  Initial startup will only occur when a new process goes on-line.  This will be included in the process equipment O&M guidance for the process.

- Normal Operations:
Procedures are located in the vendor's O&M guidance for normal operations.



- Temporary Operations:
Temporary operations may occur in instances such as change over of storage vessels or when repairing or servicing the feed lines. Temporary operations should occur any time there are short-term operation not considered to be normal or emergency, for whatever reason.

- Emergency Shutdown: 
Emergency shutdown is required for power outages, leaks, and alarms.  Emergency shutdown procedures are located in the vendor's O&M guidance.

- Emergency Operations:
Emergency operations are unanticipated and short term.  Specific procedures that describe emergency operations are covered in the vendor's O&M guidance.

- Normal Shutdown: 
Procedures are located in the vendor's O&M guidance. Normal shutdown occurs when the system is required to be taken off line for maintenance, equipment change-out, etc.  These procedures are included in the vendor's O&M guidance for the process.

3.0	Training

RMP Initial Training Policy

· All city employees currently involved in any aspect of operation or maintenance of the chlorination process shall be immediately certified in accordance with 40 CFR 68.71 (a) (2), that

the employee has the required knowledge, skills, and abilities to safely carry out the duties and responsibilities as specified in the operating procedures.

· For those employees currently involved in any aspect of operation of the chlorination process who cannot be certified due to lack of demonstrated knowledge, skill, or abilities, the employee shall discontinue all tasks involved with the covered process until either (1) interim training can be provided to cover the gaps in the knowledge, skill, or ability, or (2) the employee has undergone comprehensive RMP Initial Training.

· The RMP Initial Training program shall be developed and implemented prior to December 31, 2001.

· RMP Initial Training shall be provided to all new employees or any employee who will be involved in operation of the chlorination process before the employee is allowed to work with the chlorination process.

RMP Refresher Training Policy

The following guidelines shall be followed for the RMP Refresher Training:

· All employees involved in operation of the chlorination process shall have refresher training in accordance with 40 CFR 68.71 (a) (2) (b).  

· Refresher training frequency shall be at least every three years, or more frequent, if necessary.

· Refresher training needs shall be identified and reviewed annually.

· Employees shall have input into identification of training needs through an employee feedback evaluation form. 

· During years when a compliance audit is performed, the schedule for the annual refresher training needs assessment shall be coordinated in order to consider the findings of the compliance audit.

Training Documentation  

The RMP training records will be kept on file in the personnel training records.  

4.0	Mechanical Integrity

The purpose of this section is preservation and maintenance of the integrity of the chlorination process equipment.  Whereas operating procedures focus on human activities, this section has as its goal the proper, ongoing functi

oning of equipment.  Of course, this too depends on the activities of facility personnel, specifically the performance of preventive maintenance functions.  All replacement equipment and/or parts meet vendor design specification.

5.0	Management of Change

The Management of Change (MOC) program assists the plant staff in maintaining control over changes to the processes by subjecting such changes to strict technical review and formal authorization.  The MOC program also ensures that process changes affecting existing procedures are reflected in new written procedures.  

Written Procedures to Manage Changes         

Whenever a design or operational change is proposed, the responsible person must determine if any of the following will change:

· process chemistry, changes in chemical reaction, or chemical phase
· quantity or composition of chlorine, additives, or reactants that would affect the chlorine
· safe operating limits pertaining to temperature, pressure, and flow rates
· consequences of deviation from safe operating limits
· operating procedures
· electrical classification or materials of construction
· design specifications
· other affected equipment, operations, or procedures
· If any of the items listed above are changed by the proposed process change, then MOC procedures shall be followed .



Considerations Prior to Any Change

· Technical Basis for the Proposed Change:  There shall be a sound technical basis for the change.  In other words, the change should bring about an improvement in production, quality, efficiency, safety, or cost.  If there is not a sound technical basis for the change, it shall not be undertaken.

· Impact of Change on Safety and Health:  If the otherwise advantageous change would bring about a detrimental effect on employee safety or health, there shall be counter measures taken to ensure that the level of safety and health is not adversely affected after the change.  If the avoidance of adverse safety and health effects canno

t be achieved, the change shall not be undertaken.

· Modifications to Operating Procedures:  If the change will affect any operating procedures pertaining to the process, revised procedures shall be developed immediately before the change goes into effect.  Affected employees shall be trained in the procedural changes.

· Necessary Time Period for the Change:  With the exception of emergency changes, there shall be an ample amount of time allowed for scrutiny before full implementation of the change is allowed.  Time shall be allowed for assessing impacts on safety and health, modifying procedures, and informing and training affected employees before the change is implemented.

· Authorization Requirements for the Proposed Change:  Authorization shall be in writing and made by the person or persons in responsible charge of the operation of the chlorination process.

6.0	Pre-startup Review

This element of the RMP exists to ensure that, before a new or modified process is brought on-line with chlorine, the process is thoroughly examined for safety, design integrity, and adequacy.  By implementing this procedure, facility personnel can prevent potentially dangerous makeshift modifications from being made and ensure that new or modified processes have been built in accordance with sound design and installation standards.

The pre-startup review will be performed for new and modified stationary sources as required.

Prior Confirmation

· Construction and equipment: This review is routinely performed for new construction performed by outside contractors as part of job completion verification and for the release of construction payments.  However, it is just as important to confirm compliance with design specifications and codes when the work has been performed by internal personnel.  
	
· New stationary sources:  Making the PHA a part of design/construction services is the surest way to avoid a violation of this part of the rule.  Therefore a PHA will be conducted pri

or to start up of the proposed new stationary site.

· Training: Training will be performed by the power equipment vendor to City personnel.  Training will be documented as part of the pre-startup review.


7.0	Compliance Audits

Compliance audits will be performed to ensure that the plan procedures are adequate and that they are being followed by affected employees.  This plan is intended to be a living document that responds to changes in operations and personnel.  As such, it is necessary to check periodically to verify that (1) the plan still meets the needs of the facility, (2) the plan meets the requirements of the rules, and (3) that facility personnel are adhering to the plan.

A compliance audit will be conducted at least every three years.  A more frequent audit schedule may be used at the discretion of the facility responsible person.  Factors influencing a more frequent schedule include:

· high employee turnover
· change in responsible person
· frequent changes to process equipment or procedures.

Although the rule states that the audit shall be conducted by at least one knowledgeable person, the level of effort required and amount of detail examined makes it more effective to conduct the audit with two or three personnel.  The audit team shall be familiar with: (1) the rule requirements, (2) the plan document, (3) the physical process, and (4) the covered chemical. 

The audit report will take into account every requirement of the regulation, and will include findings and recommendations.  

Findings resulting from the audit will be tracked and recommended actions to correct deficiencies or improve the RMP will be documented for completeness.  Participants involved in implementing recommendations will be noted for future reference for feedback on the time, effort, and cost required to correct the deficiencies. 

8.0	Incident Investigation

Incident investigations will be performed to determine the cause of accidental releases that resulted in, or cou

ld have resulted in, endangerment to public health and the environment.  Recommendations resulting from the investigation will be implemented as appropriate to prevent a reoccurrence.

An incident investigation will be performed for each incident resulting in, or which could reasonably have resulted in, a catastrophic release.

As required by the rule, the investigation will be initiated no more than 48 hours after the incident.  Prompt investigation will ensure that evidence is fresh and recollection of facts associated with the release is more accurate.
The core incident investigation team includes the following staff:

· Fire Chief
· Compliance/Regulatory Officer
· Public Works Superintendent
· Process Equipment Representative

Depending on the nature of the incident, and the circumstances surrounding it, other knowledgeable personnel will participate as appropriate.

It is essential that measures be taken promptly to prevent a reoccurrence of the incident and to avoid additional liability that would be associated with a reoccurrence. 

The relevant findings of the incident investigation will be shared with affected personnel for their information, input, and future safety.  This requirement extends to contract employees who were involved or could be involved in a similar occurrence in the future.  Such a requirement is in keeping with the intent of the RMP Employee Participation Program.

Incident investigation reporting forms will be retained for 5 years in accordance with the rule.

9.0	Employee Participation

The goal of the employee participation program (EPP) is to ensure the active involvement of affected employees in all matters related to process safety and the implementation of the RMP. The benefits of the EPP include:

· more information for making decisions affecting the chlorination processes
· greater employee awareness of actual and potential hazards
· a greater sense of employee ownership in matters of safety and health.

Employee consultation w

ill be accomplished through the following methods, as applicable:

· Participation in committees for process safety and risk management issues
· Dissemination of information at safety meetings and/or other employee meetings
· Development of position descriptions, including safety and risk management, by experienced personnel
· Other methods as appropriate

All employees will have easy access to process safety information, including the results of the PHA and the RMP document.  This will be accomplished by displaying documents and information in appropriate areas for employees' viewing, including:

· break areas
· operation control areas

Additionally, all affected employees will have access to safety, technical, and management personnel for the purpose of advancing new ideas or expressing concerns about process safety in the workplace.  Management will create and maintain a workplace atmosphere that encourages employees to speak out on safety and health issues.

10.0	Hot Work Permit

The purpose of the hot work permit is to control hot work activities in the area of the chlorination processes and prevent the occurrence of accidents associated with hot work.  Hot work is defined as work involving electric or gas welding, cutting, brazing, or similar flame or spark-producing operations.  Though not part of the definition in the rule, the term hot work may be interpreted to include work on electrical circuits or the use of unsafe tools or practices that may produce a spark in the chlorination process area.

Hot work permits will be issued in accordance with the City's procedures.

11.0	Contractors

Qualified contractors will be informed of the hazards associated with the chlorination process.  The City will determine when a contractor's work is on or adjacent to the chlorination process.  As stated in the rule, this section does not apply to incidental services, but primarily to operation, construction, maintenance, repair, renovation, or specialty work.  Although

the City must carefully select, inform, and monitor the performance of each contractor, the contractors are responsible for their own employees.

In general, the following responsibilities are required:

· The City shall:
- Check the safety performance of each contractor
- Provide safety and hazards information to the contractor 
- Ensure that safe work practices are in place at the facility
- Verify that the contractor acts responsibly on the job
- Maintain a contract employee injury and illness log related to the contractor's work in process area [OSHA requirement at 29 CFR 1910.119 (h) (2) (vi)]

· The Contractor shall:
- Make sure that its employees are trained to perform their jobs safely
- Make sure that its employees know of the process hazards associated with the work done at City facilities
- Document its employees' training
- Make sure that its employees follow the City's safety procedures
- Inform the City of any unique hazards presented by the work it is to perform or of any hazards found during performance

The responsibilities of the City are generally limited to selecting, informing, and managing the contractor.  The management of individual contractor employees is the responsibility of the contractor.

The City will use its list of pre-qualified contractors.  Each contractor on this list will have been evaluated and determined to have safety programs consistent with those of the City.  Contractors that are not on the list of pre-qualified contractors must provide the information prior to consideration for work performed on or adjacent to covered processes. 



12.0	Process Hazard Analysis

The process hazard analysis (PHA) is a critical component of the prevention program because it provides a systematic way to identify process hazards and address their control. During the performance of the PHA, equipment, procedures, and even human factors are considered and discussed.

The PHA is also the part of the prevention program that most directly reflects

the knowledge and experience of the operating personnel.  This is because their participation in this process is a requirement of the rule and, more important, they are the individuals most capable of recognizing the actual and potential hazards of the chemical processes under review.

A primary goal of the PHA is to identify:

· Scenarios or situations that could lead to operational upset or accident
· Hazards arising from those situations
· Consequences of the hazards that arise
· Likelihood and severity of the consequences
· Safeguards in place to mitigate the consequences
· Recommendations for change that would eliminate the hazard or minimize the chance of occurrence

The following pages provide details on PHA methodology and the related regulatory requirements.

The PHAs conducted for the chlorination processes at the City's wastewater treatment facility employed the What-if methodology.  This is a brainstorming approach in which facility and contract personnel, familiar with the operation and maintenance of the covered process, raise questions about operating deviations, mishaps, or human error.  The facilitator and participants ask questions such as:

· What if a chlorine container is dropped during delivery?
· What if the chlorine header is severed or ruptured?

Based on the answers to these and similar questions developed by facility personnel, the consequences of the mishaps and the resulting recommendations for improvement are identified and documented.

PHA Elements

The PHA elements consists of the following:

· What-Ifs:  this is the event that triggers the release.  It may be that none of these events has ever occurred at a particular site.  However, if they can occur, they are listed and analyzed here.

· Hazards:  this is the hazard directly attributed to the what-if event.  It is typically the release of the covered chemical.  

· Consequences:  this is the result of the hazard.  Normally it is the exposure of employees to the chemical, but can

also be fire, explosion, property damage, or other results.  There may be unforeseen results from a chemical release, despite the best efforts of the PHA team to identify all of them.

· S (everity), L (ikelihood) , R(isk) R(anking):  these parameters are given numerical values based on the experience and knowledge of the PHA team.  Severity is rated from 1, where a fatality is the potential result, to 5, where the concentration of chemical in the air is simply detectable.  Likelihood ranges from 1, meaning the frequency of occurrence could be more than once per year to 5, meaning the occurrence is not expected to be more than once during the life of the facility or process.  The risk ranking is a composite of the severity and likelihood with 1 being an occurrence of greatest concern and 10 and occurrence of little concern.

· Safeguards:  these are the facilities, equipment, procedures, design, alarms, etc. that prevent the consequences or minimize their effects.  These safeguards are already in place at the process and operational.

· Recommendations:  these are considerations for improvement to existing safeguards or development of new safeguards.  It is not necessary to implement any of these suggestions, but each one shall be considered by management.  

· Responsible Person:  this is the person that has responsibility for consideration of, and if feasible, implementation of the recommendations shown.

The PHA shall be updated and revalidated at least every 5 years, as required.

The PHA updates and revalidations shall be retained both at the facility and in the City central records.

A copy of the PHA is presented in Attachment D.

13.0	Emergency Response Program

The City of El Mirage Emergency Procedures for Chlorine Leaks was prepared for the wastewater treatment facility in compliance with OSHA standard 1910.120(q), meet the requirements of 40 CFR 68.95.  As such, this Emergency Procedure will serve as the Risk Management Programs Emergency Response Docume

nt.  A copy of this procedure is presented as Attachment E.

14.0	Outside Agency Coordination

Section (c) of 40 CFR 68.95 requires that the Emergency Response Plan be coordinated with community emergency response agencies such as the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) and the State Emergency Response Commission (SERC).  The City of El Mirage has a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) with the City of Phoenix Fire Department to provide emergency HAZ MAT response to its Wastewater Treatment Facility.  A copy of the City of Phoenix Fire Department SOP's are presented in Attachment F.


15.0	Hazard Assessment 

The hazard assessment requirement of the RMP focuses on offsite consequences and impacts resulting from the accidental release of regulated substances within an affected facility. The hazard assessment is comprised of the following five elements:


· Worst-case release scenario analysis
· Alternative release scenario analysis
· Defining of offsite impacts on population
· Defining of offsite impacts on environmental receptors
· Five-year accident history

16.0	Worst-Case Releases Scenario

The parameters for the worst-case release scenario are specifically set by the RMP rule in Sections 68.22 and 68.25.  The worst-case release quantity (2000 pounds) is equal to the greatest amount of chemical held in a vessel or the greatest amount held in a pipe. 

The worst-case quantity (2000 pounds) is assumed to be released over a ten minute time period.  This assumption applies to the chlorine at the site.  

There is no need to explain how a worst-case release might occur; cause is not an issue.  The rulemakers recognize that such a release is extremely unlikely to occur. Likewise, the meteorological conditions that must be assumed for a worst-case analysis are very unlikely to occur simultaneously.  These include a wind speed of 1.5 meters per second, an atmospheric stability class of 'F', and the highest daily maximum temperature in the previous three years.  EPA's

RMP Guidelines for Wastewater Treatment Plants Reference Tables and Equations were used instead of computer modeling for this determination.

17.0	Alternative Releases Scenario

The parameters for the alternative release scenarios are described in Sections 68.22 and 68.28 of the RMP rule.  The analysis of alternative releases allows for more realistic scenarios and more likely weather conditions.  For this analysis, the City selected a scenario that is more likely to occur than the worst-case release scenario.  The release scenarios were potential scenarios identified during the PHA.

The provisions cited EPA RMP Guidelines for Wastewater Treatment Plant Tables and Equations was used instead of computer modeling to determine the Alternative Release data.





18.0	Offsite Consequence Analysis

The offsite consequence analysis (OCA) involves determining a radius of influence for an accidental release, which is based on the distance to endpoint of the regulated substance.  The distance to endpoint for both the worse and alternative cases were established from the referenced EPA RMP Guideline document.

The offsite consequence analysis for this facility is described below.

Worse-Case Release Scenario-Chlorine
· Scenario:  Contents of full 1-ton cylinder released.
· Parameters:
-	Contents released in 10 minutes.
-	Release is outside with no containment.
· Results:   3 mile distance to endpoint.

Alternative Release Scenario-Chlorine 
· Scenario:  Valve break from cylinder.  
· Parameters:
-	Leak of vapor chlorine blows for 60 minutes before it is controlled.
-	Line diameter is 3/16  inch.
-	Surroundings are rural.
· Results:  0.1 mile distance to endpoint.

Maps illustrating the site and assorted scenarios are presented in Attachment G.

19.0	Five-year Accident History

There have been no accidental releases of controlled chemicals, within the last five years, that meet the criteria of the regulation.
